utterances: Ed Wong of the New York Times reporting from Baghdad.
Ed, thank you again.
Thanks.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Chadwick.
College basketball will be a little bit more sedate next year.
After 24 years of coaching the Temple Owls, John Chaney is quitting.
NPR's Mike Pesca looks back at Coach Chaney's colorful career.
He never won a national title.
He never even made a Final Four, but John Chaney was truly a giant of college basketball.
His teams were often called good, once or twice thought of as great or at least top ranked, but the word always associated with a Chaney team was headache.
Any opposing coach would gulp hard if he saw the word Temple on the schedule.
It seemed that Chaney's version of a perfect final score wasn't that different from Vince Lombardi's.
Something like his team 7 opponent 0.

The Temple Owls slowed it down, grinded it out, jumped into the passing lanes, broke up fast breaks, worked the ball, missed more then they made, and did everything to assure that their opponents did a little worse than they did.
Chaney believed in old fashioned values like church, family, and hard work.
Hard, hard work.
His practices routinely began at 5:30 a.m., which accomplished a few things.
One, it toughened up his team.
Two, as Chaney pointed out, it gave them the rest of the day to actually be student athletes.
And three, and Chaney knew this and embraced it, it dissuaded the most talented high school players from attending Temple.
In a press conference today, Chaney pointed to his players saying that they were his legacy.
But ever since I came here, 50-years-old, maybe the second day somebody kept asking me, how long are you going to be here?
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, you could see things swirling around, and things blowing down the street.
You could see some rotation in the clouds.
Now, I've heard cars were taken up by these tornados, and cargo containers and things like that, and that there was hail the size of softballs.
Did you see any of that?
Well, I saw an air conditioning unit was blown off the top of one of our dorms here.
And this is a seven-story dorm building, so an air conditioner unit for a building like that is pretty good size.
That was taken completely off of the roof.
And why was the campus closed?

One of the numbers I looked at last night as we were putting our paper together was a statement from the provost, that said about 60 percent of the buildings on campus had suffered either some damage to significant damage from the storm.
The campus computer center, where all the servers are hosted, lost a good portion of its roof.
The campus has a lot of trees on it, as well.
A fair number of those were completely toppled over.
And we're not talking little trees here.
As I was walking into work this morning, I saw an evergreen that's probably got a tree trunk two or three feet in diameter that was completely on its side.
And do you know when the university is going to reopen?
Well, everything I've heard from the provost and the chancellor indicates tomorrow.
They have all the facilities people that work on campus in at work and cleaning things up.
Well, I guess we'll see tomorrow if that's way it's going to be.
Jonathan Keeling is editor of The University Daily Kansan.
That's the student newspaper for the University of Kansas in Lawrence.
And Jonathan Keeling, thank you.
Thank you for having me on.
From the Studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, why giving more power to Iraqi forces may not be the best strategy right now.
But first, in Iraq, police report scores of bodies have been found in and around Baghdad in just the last day.
These killings are blamed on sectarian violence that began last month, after the bombing of a Shiite shrine in Samarra, north of Baghdad.
There are fears now of civil war.
Some experts think it is already underway.
Madeleine has an interview in a moment.
First, I spoke earlier with Reporter Ed Wong in Baghdad for the New York Times.
Ed Wong, what can you tell us about these bodies?
I've read horrific details in wire accounts from Reuters and the Associated Press.
Some of them found by a group of children playing soccer in a field, and they encounter dozens of people executed?
Well, basically, the bodies have been turning up in neighborhoods all over Baghdad.
The concentration seems to be Eastern Baghdad.
In biggest single group, more than two dozen turned up in Sadr City, which, as you know, is a vast slum.
Basically, that's the area where, on Sunday, we saw several devastating car bombs kill scores of people in a marketplace.
And the fear was that there might be reprisal killings by Shiite militia men in that neighborhood against Sunnis.
And the assumption today is that a lot of the bodies that are turning up are the results of reprisal killings.
The two dozen in Sadr City were likely done by the Mahdi Army, which is Moqtada al-Sadr's militia.
So, we're working on the theory right now that those bodies were the results of killings by militia men.
What about progress on these talks to establish the government?
These have been ongoing since the December elections.
Supposedly, the U.S.
Government is putting a lot of pressure on the various groups to come together and form a government.
I think there's supposed to be a meeting of the Parliament on Thursday.
What's happening?
Well, the meetings in Parliament will basically be a ceremonial session.
From our experience with the previous Parliament, it'll be mostly for show.
The real talks are happening behind closed doors in political offices.
Everyone knows that there is a power vacuum right now here in Iraq.
The Iraqis on the street know it.
The insurgents know it, and the Americans know it.
And basically, the goal of the U.S.
and some Iraqi politicians has been trying to get that vacuum filled.
But right now, we're seeing a lot of contentious talks among the politicians.
Ed Wong of the New York Times reporting from Baghdad.
Ed, thank you again.
Thanks.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Chadwick.
College basketball will be a little bit more sedate next year.
After 24 years of coaching the Temple Owls, John Chaney is quitting.
NPR's Mike Pesca looks back at Coach Chaney's colorful career.
He never won a national title.
He never even made a Final Four, but John Chaney was truly a giant of college basketball.
His teams were often called good, once or twice thought of as great or at least top ranked, but the word always associated with a Chaney team was headache.
Any opposing coach would gulp hard if he saw the word Temple on the schedule.
It seemed that Chaney's version of a perfect final score wasn't that different from Vince Lombardi's.
Something like his team 7 opponent 0.

The Temple Owls slowed it down, grinded it out, jumped into the passing lanes, broke up fast breaks, worked the ball, missed more then they made, and did everything to assure that their opponents did a little worse than they did.
Chaney believed in old fashioned values like church, family, and hard work.
Hard, hard work.
His practices routinely began at 5:30 a.m., which accomplished a few things.
One, it toughened up his team.
Two, as Chaney pointed out, it gave them the rest of the day to actually be student athletes.
And three, and Chaney knew this and embraced it, it dissuaded the most talented high school players from attending Temple.
In a press conference today, Chaney pointed to his players saying that they were his legacy.
But ever since I came here, 50-years-old, maybe the second day somebody kept asking me, how long are you going to be here?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Chaney's voice is usually raspier then that and his tone was often less temperate.
One time he stormed into a press conference given by a rival coach, John Calipari, and threatened him to a fight.
Sportswriter and NPR Morning Edition commentator John Feinstein assesses Chaney's impact on the game.
His intensity will be remembered.
His emotions will be remembered.
I think the tape of the incident with John Calipari will be shown whenever people talk about him, as will some of his other tirades because that's a big part of John Chaney.
But I think we'll also remember that he was a guy who was never afraid to take on an issue, always stood up for his athletes, and I think always stood up for African Americans in coaching.
Want to know John Chaney's legacy?
Ask the Akron Zips.
They travel to Philadelphia tomorrow to play Temple in the second tier National Invitation Tournament.
You know they gulped hard when they saw the draw.
Temple, John Chaney, headache.
Mike Pesca, NPR News, New York.
From NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, saying it's immoral and unethical, a group of doctors calls for an end to force-feeding at the Guantanamo Bay detention center.
But first, President Bush today says he's troubled by the political storm over the Dubai Ports deal.
In the face of overwhelming Congressional opposition, Dubai Ports World says it will allow an American entity to take over its U.S.
operations.
The President called the United Arab Emirates a committed ally in the war on terror, but said Congress was still very much opposed to it.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: I'm concerned about a broader message this issue could send to our friends and allies around the world, particularly in the Middle East.
In order to win the war on terror, we have got to strengthen our relationships and friendships with moderate Arab countries in the Middle East.
Joining me, as he does every Friday, is NPR's senior correspondent, Juan Williams, to talk about how the week looked in Washington.
And Juan, we'll start with the Dubai Ports World story.
It's still unclear just who will run the ports now.
Any thoughts on who this American entity could possibly be?
Well, there's all sorts of talk, Madeleine, about Halliburton and other major companies, but so far, denials coming from that direction.
You know, what's interesting too is there's questions about exactly how the deal would be checked, monitored to make sure that in fact Dubai Ports was not the controlling interest any longer.
Who is going to make that decision?
You have the courts, the foreign investment panel, looking at Dubai Ports and having approved it.
Are they going to use the same standard in approving a deal for a company that claims not to be based in the Arab world?
You know, what have their standards been with regard to the Chinese, to any other foreign entity that's coming into the United States?
So it's not just who owns it.
It's a question of who will acknowledge ownership and what's the process for giving them approval for the purchase?
Well, I'm sure Congress will be keeping a keen eye on that.
They were in open rebellion, Republicans in open rebellion against their leader, President Bush.
What does this mean for him politically?
Boy, these are rough seas.
He needs a port in the storm right now, Madeleine.
The last few hours, what you've heard around Washington from the Republicans is this is done.
It's over.
We've taken the hit.
Now it's time to move on.
But from the Democratic perspective, the damage continues.
Clearly what you had was a, literally a pitchfork rebellion among the grassroots, especially on the Republican side, saying we don't want Arab ownership of U.S.

ports, and the White House having been slow on the pickup, slow to respond, then finds that the, especially the House of Representatives, a literal stampede away from the President, forcing him into more and more of a lame duck status, one who can't even control his own troops, Madeleine.
